subject: standardized spelling and ambiguous symbols
msgSnippet: Hi Paige, ... With a phonemic script one has two options, spell as you think you speak or spell a standard base dialect that nearly everyone understands.
messageBody:
Hi Paige,

Thanks for your comments. Paige wrote:

> If I, as an American, can understand Australian English or British
> English when spoken, I surely should be able to understand it when
> written [phonemically] in QS.

With a phonemic script one has two options,
spell as you think you speak or spell a standard base dialect that
nearly everyone understands.

Standardization came about primarily because that is what publishers
wanted. It is not a "hold over." Publisher's still want
standardized spelling.

Readers of the popular press would also prefer it because it permits
them to ramp up their reading speed. It is not because they could
not understand it if it were written in dialect that they could
understand if they heard someone speak it.

The primary objection to any kind of spelling reform is not that it
cannot be read but that it takes more effort and reduces reading
speed.

No one has really studied how long it would take for someone to
regain their reading speed in a new orthography because it is
probably more than the 3 weeks -- the typical limit for
psychological research where students are the subjects.

----------

Paige wrote: [Once standdardized] "the alphabet stops being a
relatively accurate representation of speech and over time the
divergence between spoken English and written English will
inevitably increase, and given enough time, we will be back in the
same boat we are in now."

SB: This is true and is precisely the argument Johnson used for not
making an attempt to align print and speech at the time of the 1755
standardization.

Standardized spelling will need to have minor revisions every 50
years or so. At least that has been the experience with languages
that attempt to preserve their alphabets such as Spanish and
Portuguese.

Given the divergence of of English dialects, standardization may
include the use of [purposely ambiguous] symbols that have different
interpretations in different regions. Phonemically, the short o may
refer to BBC-English but as standardized it may also be interpreted
as the NBC-English [ah].

If there is a terminal R in the standardized spelling, non-rhotic
speakers will ignore it the same way they ignore it in the
traditional spelling. One could have a symbol that had three
interpretations: either schwa, or schwa r, or syllabic r.

The point is that in a world english, the divergence between speech
communities is probably greater than the divergence from the alphbet
that would be observed after a 50 year time interval.

Regards,

Steve
